title: Calculating in Series-Parallel Circuits

questions.prompt:
Using the rated resistance values in the circuit shown above,
what is the effective total resistance of the R2 and R3 portion of the circuit?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(R2*R3/(R2+R3),3)] ohms
options.feedback: Right! You used the formula for parallel resistances since R2 and R3 are connected in parallel!

options.option: [var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(R2+R3,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! R2 and R3 are connected in parallel, not in series. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(R1+R2+R3,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! You incorrectly calculated the total series resistance of these resistors. R2 and R3 are in parallel. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(R1*R2/(R1+R2),3)] ohms
options.feedback: You're on the right track, but you incorrectly used the values for R1 and R2, rather than R2 and R3.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(R1+R2,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! You incorrectly chose the series total of R1 and R2, rather than the parallel total of R2 and R3. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(R1*R3/(R1+R3),3)] ohms
options.feedback: You're on the right track, but you incorrectly used the values for R1 and R3, rather than R2 and R3.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(R2*R3/(R2+R3)*(0.97-Math.random()/10),3)] ohms
options.feedback: Are you guessing? Or did you just make an error using the formula for calculating total resistance for parallel resistors. Check out the tutorial, if this isn't clear.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(R2*R3/(R2+R3)*(0.77-Math.random()/10),3)] ohms
options.feedback: Are you guessing? Or did you just make an error using the formula for calculating total resistance for parallel resistors. Check out the tutorial, if this isn't clear.

questions.prompt: What is the effective total resistance of all the resistors in the circuit?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(R1+R2*R3/(R2+R3),3)] ohms
options.feedback: Right! R1 is in series with the parallel R2 and R3!

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(R1+R2+R3,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! This circuit is a combination of series and parallel, not just series. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(1/(1/R1+1/R2+1/R3),3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! This circuit is a combination of series and parallel, not just parallel. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(R3+R1*R2/(R1+R2),3)] ohms
options.feedback: You're on the right track, but you seem to have mixed up the values of R1, R2, and R3.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(R2+R1*R3/(R1+R3),3)] ohms
options.feedback: You're on the right track, but you seem to have mixed up the values of R1, R2, and R3.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(10*R1+100*R2*R3/(R2+R3),3)] ohms
options.feedback: Are you guessing? Or did you just make a math error? Check out the tutorial, if unsure.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(10*R3+100*R1*R2/(R1+R2),3)] ohms
options.feedback: Are you guessing? Or did you just make a math error? Check out the tutorial, if unsure.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(10*R2+100*R1*R3/(R1+R3),3)] ohms
options.feedback: Are you guessing? Or did you just make a math error? Check out the tutorial, if unsure.

questions.prompt:
Using the rated resistance values in the circuit shown above,
what should be the total current delivered by the battery to this circuit?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2*R3/(R2+R3)),3)] A
options.feedback: Right! You used the total circuit resistance to find the total circuit current. Good job!

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2+R3),3)] A
options.feedback: No, these resistors are not just in series, but a combination of series and parallel. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(1/(1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3)),3)] A
options.feedback: No, these resistors are not just in parallel, but a combination of series and parallel. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R3+R1*R2/(R1+R2)),3)] A
options.feedback: You're on the right track, but it seems you've mixed up the values of R1, R2, and R3.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R2+R1*R3/(R1+R3)),3)] A
options.feedback: You're on the right track, but it seems you've mixed up the values of R1, R2, and R3.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs((R1+R2*R3/(R2+R3))/100000,3)] A
options.feedback: Are you guessing? Or did you just make a math error? Find the total circuit resistance and then use Ohm's law to calculate the current. See the tutorial for more.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(9/(2*R3+.1*R1*R2/(R1+R2)),3)] A
options.feedback: Are you guessing? Or did you just make a math error? Find the total circuit resistance and then use Ohm's law to calculate the current. See the tutorial for more.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(9/(2*R2+.1*R1*R3/(R1+R3)),3)] A
options.feedback: Are you guessing? Or did you just make a math error? Calculate the total circuit resistance and then use Ohm's law to calculate the current. See the tutorial for more.

questions.prompt: What should be the voltage drop across R1?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2*R3/(R2+R3))*R1,3)] V
options.feedback: Right! You can use the total circuit current to determine the voltage drop across the series resistor R1. Good job!

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2+R3)*R1,3)] V
options.feedback: No, you chose the voltage across R1, as if all the resistors were in series, but here you must use the series-parallel circuit current. If unclear, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2+R3)*R2,3)] V
options.feedback: No, you actually chose the voltage across R2, as if all the resistors were in series, rather than the voltage across R1. If unclear, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2+R3)*R3,3)] V
options.feedback: No, you actually chose the voltage across R3, as if all the resistors were in series rather than the voltage across R1. If unclear, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R2+R1*R3/(R1+R3))*R2,3)] V
options.feedback: No, you seem to be on the right track, but did you get the resistor values mixed up? If unclear, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R3+R1*R2/(R1+R2))*R3,3)] V
options.feedback: No, you seem to be on the right track, but did you get the resistor values mixed up? If unclear, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(Math.pow(10,Math.log10(R1)-Math.floor(Math.log10(R1))),3)] V
options.feedback: Are you just guessing or make a math error? If unclear, check the tutorial.

questions.prompt: What should be the voltage drop across R2?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; var P = R2*R3/(R2+R3); Math.toSigFigs(9*P/(R1+P),3)] V
options.feedback: Right! The total circuit current determines the voltage drop across the parallel resistors R2 and R3. Good job!

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2*R3/(R2+R3))*R1,3)] V
options.feedback: No, you chose the voltage drop across R1, not across R2 (or R3).

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2+R3)*R1,3)] V
options.feedback: No, you chose the voltage across R1, as if all the resistors were in series, but here you must use the series-parallel circuit current. If unclear, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2+R3)*R2,3)] V
options.feedback: No, this would be the voltage across R2, if all the resistors were in series. If unclear, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2+R3)*R3,3)] V
options.feedback: No, this would be the voltage across R3, if all the resistors were in series. If unclear, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; var P = R1*R3/(R1+R3); Math.toSigFigs(9*P/(R2+P),3)] V
options.feedback: No, you seem to be on the right track, but did you get the resistor values mixed up? If unclear, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; var P = R2*R1/(R2+R1); Math.toSigFigs(9*P/(R3+P),3)] V
options.feedback: No, you seem to be on the right track, but did you get the resistor values mixed up? If unclear, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(Math.pow(10,Math.log10(R1)-Math.floor(Math.log10(R1))),3)] V
options.feedback: Are you just guessing or make a math error? If unclear, check the tutorial.

questions.prompt: So, what will be the current through R2?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; var P = R2*R3/(R2+R3); Math.toSigFigs(9*P/(R1+P)/R2,3)] A
options.feedback: Excellent! The voltage across the parallel resistors will determine the current through R2. Good work!

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(9/R1,3)] A
options.feedback: No, are you guessing? The circuit is more complicated than just one resistor. The tutorial may help.

options.option: [var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(9/R2,3)] A
options.feedback: No, are you guessing? The circuit is more complicated than just one resistor. The tutorial may help.

options.option: [var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; Math.toSigFigs(9/R3,3)] A
options.feedback: No, are you guessing? The circuit is more complicated than just one resistor. The tutorial may help.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(R1+R2+R3),3)] A
options.feedback: No, these resistors are not just in series, but a combination of series and parallel. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance;Math.toSigFigs(9/(1/(1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3)),3)] A
options.feedback: No, these resistors are not just in parallel, but a combination of series and parallel. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; var P = R2*R3/(R2+R3); Math.toSigFigs(9*P/(R1+P)/R3,3)] A
options.feedback: Oops! You chose the current through R3 instead of R2.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.nominalResistance; var R2 = r2.nominalResistance; var R3 = r3.nominalResistance; var P = R2*R3/(R2+R3); Math.toSigFigs(9*P/(R2+P)/R1,3)] A
options.feedback: Are you guessing, or maybe made a math error? Check the tutorial if unsure.

COMMENT: Bonus for time < 60 sec: 8 pts. Max score: 20 pts.
